title: HW1 Solutions
content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>A thread for the homework 1 solutions:</paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/GQjeXuC7D1PM5npnIotmftvF" filename="hw01codesolution.zip"/><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/aO8NnPYdzjOpEyEphrp1j0nZ" filename="hw01_solution.pdf"/><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/wfhyVdY3qm8RjcFtilajxu8o" filename="hw01_question.pdf"/></document>
document: A thread for the homework 1 solutions:

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>For 1(c), shouldn't  $$∇_wL(w)$$ be a row vector, not a column vector, because w is a column vector?</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: For 1(c), shouldn't  $$∇_wL(w)$$ be a row vector, not a column vector, because w is a column vector?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I believe that the convention from HW0 is that $\frac{\partial L}{\partial w}$, where $L$ is a scalar and $w$ is a column vector, is a row vector. Gradient on the other hand, is column vector.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: I believe that the convention from HW0 is that $\frac{\partial L}{\partial w}$, where $L$ is a scalar and $w$ is a column vector, is a row vector. Gradient on the other hand, is column vector.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I was confused by this too, but if you consider the gradient descent basic equation, that's a simple reference implying that the gradient is a column vector. I think the EECS 127 notes clarify this too: https://ryeii.github.io/CS127-227A/note/main.pdf</paragraph></document>
comments.document: I was confused by this too, but if you consider the gradient descent basic equation, that's a simple reference implying that the gradient is a column vector. I think the EECS 127 notes clarify this too: https://ryeii.github.io/CS127-227A/note/main.pdf

comments.content: Can someone explain why $$x_i = V\tilde{x}_i$$? I don't get that when I use the definition that \tilde{x}_i is ith column of \tilde{X}, and $$\tilde{X} = U\Sigma_1$$
comments.document: Can someone explain why $$x_i = V\tilde{x}_i$$? I don't get that when I use the definition that \tilde{x}_i is ith column of \tilde{X}, and $$\tilde{X} = U\Sigma_1$$

comments.content:
<document version="2.0"><paragraph>My understanding is that first we have </paragraph><math>X = \tilde{X}V^T</math><paragraph>and by definition </paragraph><math>X = \begin{bmatrix}
\mathbf{x}_1^T \\
\mathbf{x}_2^T \\
\vdots \\
\mathbf{x}_n^T
\end{bmatrix}</math><paragraph>so we have the row-wise relationship</paragraph><math>\mathbf{x}_i^T = \tilde{\mathbf{x}}_i^T V^T</math><paragraph>then take the transpose of both side:</paragraph><math>\mathbf{x}_i = V\tilde{\mathbf{x}}_i</math></document>
comments.document:
My understanding is that first we have 

$$X = \tilde{X}V^T$$

and by definition 

$$X = \begin{bmatrix}
\mathbf{x}_1^T \\
\mathbf{x}_2^T \\
\vdots \\
\mathbf{x}_n^T
\end{bmatrix}$$

so we have the row-wise relationship

$$\mathbf{x}_i^T = \tilde{\mathbf{x}}_i^T V^T$$

then take the transpose of both side:

$$\mathbf{x}_i = V\tilde{\mathbf{x}}_i$$

comments.content: Hello, I believe the solution for $c_1$ has an extra $\eta$ term. I found this while deriving this on my own paper, and also, plugging in the final value listed would duplicate the $\eta$ term.
comments.document: Hello, I believe the solution for $c_1$ has an extra $\eta$ term. I found this while deriving this on my own paper, and also, plugging in the final value listed would duplicate the $\eta$ term.

comments.content: Same for the next part, there is an extra $\eta^2$
comments.document: Same for the next part, there is an extra $\eta^2$

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Towards the beginning of this course, I was planning on creating a detailed course reader for people to use that would go through every homework question in detail as prep for the final exam. </paragraph><paragraph>This class is a lot of work, so I didn't get farther than HW1, but if anyone is reviewing this homework, this super detailed guide could help a lot!</paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/EbyE4RUoNB0NEcEpsli6Uo8v" filename="A_Review_of_the_Main_Conceptual_Topics_of_CS182.pdf"/></document>
comments.document:
Towards the beginning of this course, I was planning on creating a detailed course reader for people to use that would go through every homework question in detail as prep for the final exam. 

This class is a lot of work, so I didn't get farther than HW1, but if anyone is reviewing this homework, this super detailed guide could help a lot!
